awd_titl_txt: CMMI-EPSRC: Response to CO2 Exposure of Concrete with Natural Supplementary Cementitious Materials (RENACEM)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported under the NSF 18-067, NSF Engineering-UKRI Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council, funding opportunity.  Concrete is the most versatile building material in the United States, used to construct and repair buildings, transportation systems, and energy infrastructure. The development, maintenance, and repair of concrete infrastructure is vital to national growth, prosperity, citizen safety, and welfare. Concrete is a complex, composite material, made of a mixture of mineral aggregates, water, portland cement, and additives that enhance its properties in the initial fluid generated upon mixing and in its final hardened state. Most modern concrete mixtures contain supplementary cementitious materials (SCMs) that partially replace portland cement to improve concrete long-term durability, lower costs, and reduce CO2 emissions associated with concrete production. The most commonly used SCMs are waste-derived, especially residual ashes from coal-fired power plants. However, changes in industrial processes and increasing demand for SCMs are leading to a shortage of high quality, waste-derived SCMs. Natural SCMs, such as calcined clays and volcanic minerals, are a promising alternative to waste-derived SCMs, and their use is rising. Advantages of natural SCMs stem in large part from their chemistry and mineralogy; they are more homogeneous than waste-derived materials, which aids in quality control. Moreover, they also provide economic, environmental, and performance benefits. The use of SCMs, however, also has a downside, i.e., the propensity to increase chemical carbonation reactions between the concrete and atmospheric CO2, which can result in corrosion of steel reinforcement, loss of strength, and cracking. Therefore, it is important to develop a better understanding of the carbonation processes in concrete containing natural SCMs in order to identify materials and mixtures that that impart benefits without sacrificing performance. By combining research expertise and resources between institutions in the United States and the United Kingdom, this project will investigate interactions between concrete containing new and promising sources of natural SCMs and CO2, new methods of testing and damage detection, and new strategies to minimize the impact of the degradation.  This research can lead to the production of higher quality, lower environmental-impact concrete. As such, this research can have a broad impact on the lifespan and sustainability of concrete infrastructure, which is critical for infrastructure globally, sustainability, and workforce development. National prosperity depends on a global, sustainable approach to resource utilization and protection. Students working on this project will gain valuable international research experiences. 

Considering that the construction field is increasing its use of natural SCMs in concrete, understanding the contribution of natural SCMs toward carbonation degradation will be critical for the viability of this technology. Furthermore, manipulating the composition of the systems to reduce or prevent carbonation is possible, but has not previously been explored. This Response to CO2 Exposure of Concrete with Natural Supplementary Cementitious Materials (RENACEM) project is a joint United States-United Kingdom collaboration among researchers at the University of Texas at Austin, University of Leeds, and University of Sheffield to elucidate the fundamental science controlling the long-term performance of concrete produced with natural SCMs.  This project will investigate the chemical interactions between concrete and atmospheric CO2 and its transport to identify meaningful methodologies for their assessment. This will underpin the adoption of new methods for testing carbonation of concrete with natural SCMs and new predictive models. RENACEM comprises five work packages (WPs). WP1 will focus on advanced characterization of natural SCMs and the development of materials with reduced carbonation susceptibility. WP2 will establish the physicochemical mechanisms governing carbonation of natural SCM-based materials, interlinking their mineralogy, phase assemblages, and microstructure with their response to natural and accelerated carbonation.  WP3 will investigate in situ monitoring of pH and relative humidity changes upon CO2 exposure of natural SCM-based concrete using advanced fiber optic sensing networks. WP4 will move beyond the state of the art in modeling of carbonation to bring new predictive capabilities for both carbonation rate and extent, including the total extent of CO2 uptake by concrete in service.  Finally, WP5 will focus on project management, including risk and progress assessment, and implementation of planned impact activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
RENACEM was a joint US-UK collaboration investigating the fundamental science of concrete containing natural supplementary cementitious materials (SCMs) including reactions with atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2). SCMs are used in most concrete mixtures in the US and worldwide as a partial substitute for portland cement because they generally improve performance and reduce the carbon footprint. SCMs are a primary lever for reducing the environmental impact of concrete mixtures to achieve carbon neutrality. Natural SCMs are becoming increasingly common as the supply of fly ash SCMs from coal-fired power plants decreases and demand for SCMs increases. One particular concern when using SCMs in concrete is the impact on chemical carbonation reactions between the material and atmospheric CO2, which can cause degradation of the cementitious matrix and reduce pH, potentially resulting in corrosion of steel reinforcement.

In this project, we investigated several sources of natural SCMs available in the US, UK, and Europe to better understand the influence of their chemical composition and processing on chemical reactivity and performance. Of increasing interest in the concrete industry for their potential as SCMs are clays, which are abundant worldwide, but have highly variable compositions. Clays with varying purity, both kaolinite and montmorillonite-based, were calcined and examined. There is a trade-off generally between the purity of the clay and its performance, with higher purity clays showing greater reactivity but having a detrimental impact on concrete fresh-state properties (workability). The role of clay composition on concrete performance from the fresh and hardened state was examined, and strategies for blending materials for optimized performance were developed. Gypsum adjustment was found to be key to improving the early-age reaction kinetics and performance of cements containing calcined clay, with the optimum amount dominantly driven by clay surface area.

The US is experiencing a rapid shift in the primary type of cement produced, moving from a “Type I” ordinary portland cement (OPC) to a “Type IL” portland limestone cement (PLC). Accordingly, natural SCMs were tested with PLCs, creating blends that approach what is popularly called LC3 (for limestone-calcined clay-cement). Blends of natural SCMs, including calcined clays and volcanic minerals, were tested with PLCs and with blends of OPC and limestone. It was determined that there are multiple pathways to introduce LC3 to the US market, taking advantage of regionally available cements and minerals, some of which can be blended at the concrete ready-mix plant and some of which are better managed by blending at a cement plant to control quality. Furthermore, there is potential for blending calcined clay-limestone-gypsum to develop a manufactured, low-CO2 SCM with varying composition and performance. Locally available dolomite reserves were found to be suitable for use instead of limestone in these blends. There is significant regional variation in natural SCM availability across the US, and having a better fundamental understanding of the relationship between SCM and blend composition and performance will assist in the rapid implementation needed to achieve carbon neutrality.

Carbonation of concrete has received increasing attention in the concrete research community for multiple reasons. There is an interest in increasing the extent of chemical reactions between CO2 and concrete that allow the concrete to act as a “sponge” for atmospheric CO2. On the other hand, the chemical carbonation reactions degrade the integrity of the concrete and reduce pH, potentially resulting in corrosion of steel reinforcement. The presence of SCMs enhances the carbonation reaction, resulting in more CO2 consumed as well as more degradation and potential for corrosion of reinforcing steel. In this project, the carbonation process of materials produced with natural SCMs was examined experimentally in pastes, mortars and concretes, and results were then used to underpin the creation of a reactive transport model. This modeling tool will facilitate the prediction of carbonation performance for SCM-containing concrete, thereby aiding the selection of the right SCM-cement combination depending on performance requirements.

Somewhat surprisingly, the more reactive SCMs (e.g., higher kaolinite content calcined clays) had slower carbonation rates than the less reactive SCMs (impure clays). Increase in curing duration was also found to improve carbonation resistance. There is a balance between the consumption of calcium hydroxide by the SCM, leading to faster carbonation, and the refinement of pore structure caused by the SCM and curing, leading to slower carbonation. Another observation is that carbonation can be altered through additives or by varying the type of cement (OPC, PLC, or Type IV) used.

This research has demonstrated that there are multiple strategies that can be used to either enhance or slow down carbonation depending on the end goal. Carbonation testing approaches, like phenolphthalein indicator practices and carbonation environments, were critically examined.  Different analytical techniques were used to gain insights into the physical and chemical changes occurring along the carbonation front, which is key for accurately predicting long-term carbonation performance of clay-containing concrete.
